Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics

From 2001 through 2007 I was the founding Chair of the Department of Applied Mathematics and Statistics (AMS) within the Baskin School of Engineering (BSoE) at the University of California, Santa Cruz (UCSC); currently I'm a full Professor of Statistics in AMS. I'm the author or co-author of about 150 contributions to the open academic literature in statistical methods and applications; at present I supervise 7 Ph.D. students and an M.S. student. In 2007 I won a campus-wide Excellence in Teaching award.

I've been a private statistical consultant since 1979; my work focuses on helping people solve difficult problems involving uncertainty quantification (statistical inference and prediction) and decision under uncertainty (statistical decision-making). In the intervening 35 years I've worked on well over 100 paid projects for dozens of clients, including topics in the fields of medicine, health policy, environmental risk assessment and eCommerce, with private project reports, publications in the open literature and legal consulting/testimony the usual outcomes.

I offered statistical consulting advice in a short-term project on forecasting the future demand for 30 million Amazon products simultaneously. This involved developing (a) Bayesian hierarchical dynamic linear (state-space) models and other forecasting techniques, and using Bayesian model averaging to combine their predictions,  (b) creating new metrics for measuring the performance of these models, and (c) using Bayesian decision theory to make optimal inventory planning choices.
Senior Director of the Center of Excellence in Statistical Research, eBay Research Labs

I was brought into eBay Research Labs to develop a significant presence for statistical research within the eBay research environment, to complement existing strengths in econometrics and machine learning. Other statisticians in my group and I worked on improved A/B testing, optimal design and analysis of large-scale observational studies, and anomaly detection via massively parallel time series modeling, to quickly identify unusual changes in business-relevant quantitative indicators so that root-cause analysis can begin.
